elements.content: Four new cadmium(II) complexes [Cd2(bz)4(H2O)4(μ2-hmt)]·Hbz·H2O (1), [Cd3(bz)6(H2O)6(μ2-hmt)2]·6H2O (2), [Cd(pa)2(H2O)(μ2-hmt)] n (3), and {[Cd3(ac)6(H2O)3(μ3-hmt)2]·6H2O} n (4) with hexamine (hmt) and monocarboxylate ions, benzoate (bz), phenylacetate (pa), or acetate (ac) have been synthesized and characterized structurally. Structure determinations reveal that 1 is dinuclear, 2 is trinuclear, 3 is a one-dimensional (1D) infinite chain, and 4 is a two-dimensional (2D) polymer with fused hexagonal rings consisting of CdII and hmt. All the CdII atoms in the four complexes (except one CdII in 2) possess seven-coordinate pentagonal bipyramidal geometry with the various chelating bidentate carboxylate groups in equatorial sites. One of the CdII ions in 2, a complex that contains two monodentate carboxylates is in a distorted octahedral environment. The bridging mode of hmt is μ2- in complexes 1−3 but is μ3- in complex 4. In all complexes, there are significant numbers of H-bonds, C−H/π, and π−π interactions which play crucial roles in forming the supramolecular networks. The importance of the noncovalent interactions in terms of energies and geometries has been analyzed using high level ab initio calculations. The effect of the cadmium coordinated to hmt on the energetic features of the C−H/π interaction is analyzed. Finally, the interplay between C−H/π and π−π interactions observed in the crystal structure of 3 is also studied.

elements.content: Synthesis, crystal structure, and ab initio calculations of four complexes of CdII with hexamine and monocarboxylate ions (benzoate, phenylacetate, or acetate) reveal that hexamine can participate in significant C−H/π interactions and along with other noncovalent interactions (e.g., H-bonds and π−π) play very crucial roles in forming the supramolecular architectures.
elements.clean_text: Synthesis, crystal structure, and ab initio calculations of four complexes of CdII with hexamine and monocarboxylate ions (benzoate, phenylacetate, or acetate) reveal that hexamine can participate in significant C-H/π interactions and along with other noncovalent interactions (e.g., H-bonds and π-π) play very crucial roles in forming the supramolecular architectures.

elements.content: Both discrete and extended metallo-supramolecular assemblies have received a lot of attention in recent chemical research as these species have often exhibited interesting molecular architectures and/or unusual properties. The concept of supramolecular architecture was first reported by Lehn in 1987. It is often constructed from small molecular and ion subunits by coordinate covalent bonds, hydrogen bonds, π−π and C−H/π interactions. The mode of assembly of such extended supramolecular architectures can be tuned and predicted by careful selection of the chemical structure of organic ligands and the coordination geometry of metal ions. The polycyclic tertiary amine hexamethylenetetramine (hexamine) is a potentially tetradentate neutral ligand possessing flexidentate characteristics but mostly prefers to coordinate to the metal center in the bridging bidentate fashion to produce several interesting polymers. The metal ion CdII is well suited for the construction of various coordination polymers, as its size and d10 electronic configuration permit a wide variety of coordination numbers and geometries.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Both discrete and extended metallo-supramolecular assemblies have received a lot of attention in recent chemical research as these species have often exhibited interesting molecular architectures and/or unusual properties. The concept of supramolecular architecture was first reported by Lehn in 1987. It is often constructed from small molecular and ion subunits by coordinate covalent bonds, hydrogen bonds, π-π and C-H/π interactions. The mode of assembly of such extended supramolecular architectures can be tuned and predicted by careful selection of the chemical structure of organic ligands and the coordination geometry of metal ions. The polycyclic tertiary amine hexamethylenetetramine (hexamine) is a potentially tetradentate neutral ligand possessing flexidentate characteristics but mostly prefers to coordinate to the metal center in the bridging bidentate fashion to produce several interesting polymers. The metal ion CdII is well suited for the construction of various coordination polymers, as its size and d10 electronic configuration permit a wide variety of coordination numbers and geometries.

elements.content: The C−H/π and π−π interactions are of the weakest class among possible intermolecular interactions and are intermediate in energy between the hydrogen bond and the van der Waals interaction. However, in many systems, these weak forces along with H-bonds, anion−π interactions, etc. can combine to play a decisive role in supramolecular architecture and are therefore very important in crystal engineering for the design of functional materials. In the chemistry of coordination polymers of hexamine, it was shown by using AgI and several aromatic carboxylates that C−H/π and π−π interactions between aromatic carboxylate pairs are very important in stacking two-dimensional layers to form three-dimensional networks. However, none of these reports contain any consideration or analysis of the potential ability of hexamine for participating in C−H/π interactions. The structure of hexamine suggests that it should be involved in significant C−H/π interactions similar to those found in the haloalkanes as each CH2- group is attached to two electronegative N-atoms. Moreover, it is also expected that metal coordination of hexamine would strengthen such interactions as is found in several other systems. Very recently, it has indeed been shown that intermolecular C−H/π (arene) interactions can exist between the arene rings of 2-sulfobenzoate dianion and hydrogen atoms of hmt.

However, in many systems, these weak forces along with H-bonds, anion-π interactions, etc. can combine to play a decisive role in supramolecular architecture and are therefore very important in crystal engineering for the design of functional materials. In the chemistry of coordination polymers of hexamine, it was shown by using AgI and several aromatic carboxylates that C-H/π and π-π interactions between aromatic carboxylate pairs are very important in stacking two-dimensional layers to form three-dimensional networks. However, none of these reports contain any consideration or analysis of the potential ability of hexamine for participating in C-H/π interactions. The structure of hexamine suggests that it should be involved in significant C-H/π interactions similar to those found in the haloalkanes as each CH2- group is attached to two electronegative N-atoms. Moreover, it is also expected that metal coordination of hexamine would strengthen such interactions as is found in several other systems. elements.content: Here, we report the syntheses and crystal structures of four new CdII-hexamine coordination polymers: three of them, [Cd2(bz)4(H2O)4(μ2-hmt)]·Hbz·H2O (1), [{Cd3(bz)6(H2O)6(μ2-hmt)2}·6H2O] (2), and [Cd(pa)2(H2O)(μ2-hmt)] n (3) with aromatic carboxylates, benzoate (bz), and phenylacetate (pa) and the fourth one, {[Cd3(ac)6(H2O)3(μ3-hmt)2]·6H2O} n (4) with the acetate anion. The structure determinations reveal that the nuclearity of the polymeric species and coordination modes (μ2- in complexes 1−3 and μ3- in complex 4) of hmt are very much dependent upon the carboxylate group used (Chart ). Complexes 1 and 2 are rather exceptional as all the previously reported hmt bridged metal complexes are infinite polymers except for one zinc complex ([Hhmt]2[Zn2(hmt)(NCS)6]) which is a dimer. There are strong H-bonds in all four complexes. In addition, complexes 1−3 exhibit considerable π−π stacking interactions between aromatic rings as well as C−H/π interactions between hexamine and the aromatic rings. One important aspect that has been analyzed by means of theoretical calculations at the RI-MP2/TZVP level is the energy profile of the C−H/π interactions between hexamine and the aromatic rings. As mentioned above, the C−H/π interaction is considered as the weakest type of hydrogen bond. However, the presence of a neighboring nitrogen atom coordinated to cadmium increases the acidity of the hydrogen atoms and consequently reinforces the interaction. This issue is demonstrated in the theoretical part of this manuscript, where the interplay between C−H/π and π−π interactions has also been studied. The mutual influence of both interactions leads to favorable cooperativity effects. Moreover, we have used the Bader’s theory of “atoms-in-molecules”, which has been successfully used to characterize and analyze the noncovalent interactions in the crystal. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report in which C−H/π interactions between hexamine and aromatic rings in crystal structures are analyzed by high-level ab initio methods.

elements.clean_text: 1  Cadmium(II) Complexes 1-4

elements.content: The monocarboxylic acids, hexamethylenetetramine (hmt) and CdII acetate/carbonate were purchased from Lancaster and were of reagent grade. They were used as received without further purification. Cd(ClO4)2·6H2O and Cd(OOCC6H5)2·2H2O were prepared in our laboratory by reacting cadmium carbonate with perchloric acid and benzoic acid, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

The monocarboxylic acids, hexamethylenetetramine (hmt) and CdII acetate/carbonate were purchased from Lancaster and were of reagent grade. They were used as received without further purification. Cd(ClO4)2⋅6H2O and Cd(OOCC6H5)2⋅2H2O were prepared in our laboratory by reacting cadmium carbonate with perchloric acid and benzoic acid, respectively.

elements.content: Benzoic acid (0.488 g, 4 mmol) dissolved in methanol (10 cm3) was added to a methanolic solution (10 cm3) of Cd(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.838 g, 2 mmol) and hmt (0.560 g, 4 mmol) with constant stirring. The solution was filtered to remove a small amount of precipitate that appeared immediately and the filtrate was left at room temperature. Colorless crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray determination were collected from the filtrate after a few days. Yield: 0.605 g (57%). Anal. Calc. for C41H48Cd2N4O15: C, 46.38; H, 4.56; N, 5.28; Found: C, 46.21; H, 4.68; N, 5.22%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3417, 3065, 2956, 2845, 1599, 1548, 1405, 1325, 1237, 1088, 1006, 933, 857, 812, 713, 627, 515.

elements.content: Elemental analyses (carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen) were performed using a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. IR spectra in KBr (4500−500 cm−1) were recorded using a Perkin-Elmer RXI FT-IR spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Measurements

Elemental analyses (carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen) were performed using a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. IR spectra in KBr (4500-500 cm-1) were recorded using a Perkin-Elmer RXI FT-IR spectrophotometer.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction measurement for 1, 3, and 4 was carried out using the Oxford Diffraction X-Calibur CCD System, 12293, 6169, and 7453 independent data were collected with MoKα radiation at 150 K for complexes 1, 3, and 4, respectively. The crystals were positioned at 50 mm from the CCD. 321 frames were measured with a counting time of 10 s. Data analysis was carried out with the CrysAlis program. For 2, 7246 data were collected on a Bruker Smart APEX II diffractometer, equipped with graphite monochromated MoKα radiation at 150 K, and were corrected for Lorentz-polarization effects. All four structures were solved using direct methods with the SHELXS-97 program and refined by full-matrix least-squares based on F 2 (SHELXL-97). The non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon were included in geometric positions and given thermal parameters equivalent to 1.2 times those of the atom to which they were attached. The factor for methyl hydrogen atoms was increased to 1.5. Hydrogen atoms on water molecules were located in difference Fourier maps and refined with distance constraints. While the positions of the hydrogen atoms on water molecules bound to cadmium were unequivocally determined, there was some ambiguity in the hydrogen positions of the solvent water molecules in 2. Only the highest regions of electron density were chosen for hydrogen positions. In 4 the hydrogen atoms on one of the solvent water molecules OW6 could not be located. Absorption corrections for 1, 3, and 4 were carried out using the ABSPACK program. The structures were refined on F2 to R 1 0.0388, 0.0446, 0.0302, 0.0352: wR2 0.1034, 0.1013, 0.0613, 0.0657 for 9556, 5129, 5046, 5765 data with I > 2σ(I). The crystal structure illustrations were generated using programs Ortep-3 and Mercury. Significant crystallographic data are summarized in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Data Collection and Refinement

Single crystal X-ray diffraction measurement for 1, 3, and 4 was carried out using the Oxford Diffraction X-Calibur CCD System, 12293, 6169, and 7453 independent data were collected with MoKα radiation at 150 K for complexes 1, 3, and 4, respectively. The crystals were positioned at 50 mm from the CCD. 321 frames were measured with a counting time of 10 s. Data analysis was carried out with the CrysAlis program. For 2, 7246 data were collected on a Bruker Smart APEX II diffractometer, equipped with graphite monochromated MoKα radiation at 150 K, and were corrected for Lorentz-polarization effects. All four structures were solved using direct methods with the SHELXS-97 program and refined by full-matrix least-squares based on F  2  (SHELXL-97). The non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon were included in geometric positions and given thermal parameters equivalent to 1.2 times those of the atom to which they were attached. The factor for methyl hydrogen atoms was increased to 1.5. Hydrogen atoms on water molecules were located in difference Fourier maps and refined with distance constraints. While the positions of the hydrogen atoms on water molecules bound to cadmium were unequivocally determined, there was some ambiguity in the hydrogen positions of the solvent water molecules in 2. Only the highest regions of electron density were chosen for hydrogen positions. In 4 the hydrogen atoms on one of the solvent water molecules OW6 could not be located. Absorption corrections for 1, 3, and 4 were carried out using the ABSPACK program. The structures were refined on F2 to R 1 0.0388, 0.0446, 0.0302, 0.0352: wR2 0.1034, 0.1013, 0.0613, 0.0657 for 9556, 5129, 5046, 5765 data with I > 2σ(I). The crystal structure illustrations were generated using programs Ortep-3 and Mercury. Significant crystallographic data are summarized in Table .

The geometries of all complexes studied in this work were fully optimized at the RI-MP2/TZVP level of theory using the Turbomole program. For the cadmium atom, the calculations were performed using a relativistic effective core potential (ECP28MWB). The binding energies were calculated with corrections for basis set superposition error (BSSE) by using the Boys−Bernardi counterpoise technique. For analysis of the π−π stacking interactions, more accurate energetic values were obtained at the RI-MP2/aug-cc-pVTZ//RI-MP2/TZVP level of theory. The RI-MP2 method applied to the study of noncovalent interactions is considerably faster than the MP2 and the interaction energies and equilibrium distances are almost identical for both methods. The topological analysis of the electron charge density performed for the theoretical models of the crystal structure was determined using Bader’s theory of “atoms-in-molecules” (AIM). The electronic density analysis was performed using the AIM2000 program at the B3LYP/6-31+G* level of theory. The wave function was obtained using the Gaussian-03 program. As in previous studies, the AIM theory was performed directly on experimental structures via single point calculations to estimate the intermolecular interactions. AIM is based upon those critical points where the gradient of the density, ∇ρ, vanishes. In particular, two bonded atoms are connected with a bond path through the bond critical point. Importantly, the electron density at the bond critical points roughly correlates with the strength of chemical bonds and interactions.
elements.clean_text:
Theoretical Methods

The geometries of all complexes studied in this work were fully optimized at the RI-MP2/TZVP level of theory using the Turbomole program. For the cadmium atom, the calculations were performed using a relativistic effective core potential (ECP28MWB). The binding energies were calculated with corrections for basis set superposition error (BSSE) by using the Boys-Bernardi counterpoise technique. For analysis of the π-π stacking interactions, more accurate energetic values were obtained at the RI-MP2/aug-cc-pVTZ//RI-MP2/TZVP level of theory. The RI-MP2 method applied to the study of noncovalent interactions is considerably faster than the MP2 and the interaction energies and equilibrium distances are almost identical for both methods. The topological analysis of the electron charge density performed for the theoretical models of the crystal structure was determined using Bader's theory of "atoms-in-molecules" (AIM). The electronic density analysis was performed using the AIM2000 program at the B3LYP/6-31+G* level of theory. The wave function was obtained using the Gaussian-03 program. As in previous studies, the AIM theory was performed directly on experimental structures via single point calculations to estimate the intermolecular interactions. AIM is based upon those critical points where the gradient of the density, ∇ρ, vanishes. In particular, two bonded atoms are connected with a bond path through the bond critical point. Importantly, the electron density at the bond critical points roughly correlates with the strength of chemical bonds and interactions.

elements.content: 1 and 2 are respectively the dinuclear and trinuclear molecular complexes of CdII, hmt, and benzoate. They were synthesized with a slight change in the procedure: 1 was prepared by mixing benzoic acid, Cd(ClO4)2·6H2O, and hmt in methanol, whereas 2 was prepared by the reaction of cadmium benzoate and hmt in water. 2 can also be obtained by mixing the same constituents in methanol, but the quality of the single crystals was improved when it was prepared from water. The dinuclear structure of 1 contains a cocrystallized benzoic acid molecule. To remove the benzoic acid from the structure, we used cadmium benzoate for the preparation of 2. 3 was synthesized in a method similar to that of 1, but unlike 1, 3 is a one-dimensional (1D) chain and no phenylacetic acid molecule is present in the structure. Complex 4 can be synthesized by mixing the constituents either in water or in methanol, but we obtained a better yield and diffraction quality crystals from methanol solution.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis of the Complexes

 1 and 2 are respectively the dinuclear and trinuclear molecular complexes of CdII, hmt, and benzoate. They were synthesized with a slight change in the procedure: 1 was prepared by mixing benzoic acid, Cd(ClO4)2⋅6H2O, and hmt in methanol, whereas 2 was prepared by the reaction of cadmium benzoate and hmt in water. 2 can also be obtained by mixing the same constituents in methanol, but the quality of the single crystals was improved when it was prepared from water. The dinuclear structure of 1 contains a cocrystallized benzoic acid molecule. To remove the benzoic acid from the structure, we used cadmium benzoate for the preparation of 2. 3 was synthesized in a method similar to that of 1, but unlike 1, 3 is a one-dimensional (1D) chain and no phenylacetic acid molecule is present in the structure. Complex 4 can be synthesized by mixing the constituents either in water or in methanol, but we obtained a better yield and diffraction quality crystals from methanol solution.

elements.content: In general the IR spectra show features attributable to each component of the complexes. For all complexes the characteristic antisymmetric stretching (νas) bands of the carboxylate groups appears in the usual region at 1549, 1549, 1554, and 1568 cm−1 for 1−4, respectively. Symmetric stretching (νs) for the complexes 1−4 appears at 1405, 1401, 1403, and 1419 cm−1, respectively. The binding modes of carboxylate ligands can be assessed on the basis of the difference (Δ) between asymmetric stretching, νas(COO−), and symmetric stretching νs(COO−). For monodentate carboxylate, the Δ value is usually higher (∼220 cm−1) and for bidentate symmetrical chelate Δ is much lower (∼145 cm−1). The observed differences in the complexes (144−151 cm−1) corroborate the bidentate chelating modes of the carboxylate as found in the structural analysis. The broadband in the region of ∼3400 cm−1 for all complexes could be assigned to the stretching vibration of the water molecules involved in hydrogen bonding.
elements.clean_text:
IR Spectra

In general the IR spectra show features attributable to each component of the complexes. For all complexes the characteristic antisymmetric stretching (νas) bands of the carboxylate groups appears in the usual region at 1549, 1549, 1554, and 1568 cm-1 for 1-4, respectively. Symmetric stretching (νs) for the complexes 1-4 appears at 1405, 1401, 1403, and 1419 cm-1, respectively. The binding modes of carboxylate ligands can be assessed on the basis of the difference (Δ) between asymmetric stretching, νas(COO-), and symmetric stretching νs(COO-). For monodentate carboxylate, the Δ value is usually higher (~220 cm-1) and for bidentate symmetrical chelate Δ is much lower (~145 cm-1). The observed differences in the complexes (144-151 cm-1) corroborate the bidentate chelating modes of the carboxylate as found in the structural analysis. The broadband in the region of ~3400 cm-1 for all complexes could be assigned to the stretching vibration of the water molecules involved in hydrogen bonding.

elements.content: Compound 1 upon heating loses its water molecules in one step which starts at 90 °C and is completed at 140 °C as is evident from the thermogravimetry (TG)−differential TG (DTG) curve (). The observed weight loss corresponds to five molecules of water per formula unit. The crystals turn opaque on the removal of water molecules but do not break into powder. This dehydrated species on exposure to the open atmosphere for several hours absorbs exactly five molecules of water per formula unit, and no more water molecules were absorbed on keeping for longer periods. The water loss behavior of rehydrated species as found in the TG-DTG curve is identical to that of the original sample. These observations indicate that the framework integrity of 1 remains intact upon removal of the water molecules. The dehydration behavior of complexes 2−4 is very similar. The weight loss for dehydration (up to 150 °C) for the complexes corroborates the number of water molecules present in the structure of the respective compounds (Table S1, ).

The water loss behavior of rehydrated species as found in the TG-DTG curve is identical to that of the original sample. elements.content: The dinuclear structure of 1 is shown in Figure A together with the atomic numbering scheme. The two cadmium atoms have similar seven-coordinate pentagonal bipyramidal environments being bonded to two bidentate benzoate ligands (Bz) and one water molecule in the equatorial plane and a water molecule and two nitrogen atoms from different hmt ligands in axial positions. The two equatorial planes have rms deviations of 0.106, 0.020 Å respectively with the metal atoms 0.008, 0.038 Å from the planes. Bond lengths to the benzoate oxygen atoms range from 2.369(2) to 2.447(2) Å, and are longer than the bonds to water (2.276(2)−2.308(2) Å). There is little difference between bond lengths to the axial and equatorial water molecules (). The two cadmium atoms are bridged by ligand hmt through adjacent nitrogen atoms at 2.427(2), 2.381(2) Å (μ2 bridging mode). In addition to the four chelating benzoates, there is an additional neutral benzoic acid which is inserted between the two equatorial planes and forms two strong acceptor hydrogen bonds to the two equatorially bonded water molecules and one donor hydrogen bond to a benzoate oxygen atom O(21) (Table , Figure ). The dinuclear units are linked to each other through several hydrogen bonds (Table ) involving the four water molecules bonded to the metals, the one solvent water molecule O(3) and the oxygen atoms [O(21), O(23), O(33), O(41), O(43), O(61), and O(63)] of the coordinated benzoate ligands to form a two-dimensional H-bonded network as shown in Figure .
elements.clean_text:
Description of Crystal Structures

Complex 1 

The dinuclear structure of 1 is shown in Figure A together with the atomic numbering scheme. The two cadmium atoms have similar seven-coordinate pentagonal bipyramidal environments being bonded to two bidentate benzoate ligands (Bz) and one water molecule in the equatorial plane and a water molecule and two nitrogen atoms from different hmt ligands in axial positions. The two equatorial planes have rms deviations of 0.106, 0.020 Å respectively with the metal atoms 0.008, 0.038 Å from the planes. Bond lengths to the benzoate oxygen atoms range from 2.369(2) to 2.447(2) Å, and are longer than the bonds to water (2.276(2)-2.308(2) Å). There is little difference between bond lengths to the axial and equatorial water molecules (). The two cadmium atoms are bridged by ligand hmt through adjacent nitrogen atoms at 2.427(2), 2.381(2) Å (μ2 bridging mode). In addition to the four chelating benzoates, there is an additional neutral benzoic acid which is inserted between the two equatorial planes and forms two strong acceptor hydrogen bonds to the two equatorially bonded water molecules and one donor hydrogen bond to a benzoate oxygen atom O(21) (Table , Figure ). The dinuclear units are linked to each other through several hydrogen bonds (Table ) involving the four water molecules bonded to the metals, the one solvent water molecule O(3) and the oxygen atoms [O(21), O(23), O(33), O(41), O(43), O(61), and O(63)] of the coordinated benzoate ligands to form a two-dimensional H-bonded network as shown in Figure .

The phenyl rings and hydrogen atoms, except for those belonging to water molecules, have been omitted for the sake of clarity. Hydrogen bonds are shown as dotted lines.

elements.content: The complex shows significant C−H/π and π−π interactions. One of the CH2 groups, namely, C(20), of the bridging hexamine ligand of each centrosymmetrically related (1 − x, −y, −z) dinuclear unit is involved in two Csp 3-H/π interactions with each other (Table , Figure ). There are also Csp 2-H/π interactions between H(27) of a coordinated benzoate and the benzoic acid molecule and another one between H(57) of the benzoic acid and the phenyl ring of the symmetry related (x,y,1+z) coordinated benzoate. There are strong π−π interactions between the phenyl rings of the bidentate benzoate of neighboring (−x, 1 − y, −z and 2 − x, −y, −z) dinuclear units which are also linked together by strong H-bonds. The H-bonds, C−H/π and π−π interactions together form a two-dimensional (2D) network as illustrated in Figure .

The trinuclear structure of 2 contains the same carboxylate ion (benzoate) as in 1, but here the neutral benzoic acid molecule is not present and the structure is centrosymmetric as shown in Figure A. The central metal Cd(1), situated on the center of symmetry, is six-coordinate with a distorted octahedral environment, while the outer metals Cd(2) are seven-coordinate with pentagonal bipyramidal environments. Cd(1) is bonded to two monodentate benzoates through O(11) at 2.26 (1) Å, two water molecules O(1) at 2.33 (1) Å, and two bridging hmt ligands via N(80) at 2.39(1) Å. The bonded water molecule O(1) forms a strong hydrogen bond to the unbonded benzoate oxygen atom O(13) at 2.73 (1) Å as shown in Figure A. Cd(2) is bonded to two chelating bidentate benzoates at distances ranging from 2.34(1)−2.48 (1) Å and a water molecule O(2) at 2.28 (1) Å in the equatorial plane where contributing atoms show a rms deviation of 0.14 Å, the metal atom being 0.09 (1) Å from the plane. In axial positions are the water molecule O(3) at 2.33 (1) Å and the bridging hmt through N(71) at 2.37(1) Å. The three solvent water molecules and the six coordinated water molecules in the trinuclear molecule are involved in many hydrogen bonds, as listed in Table . The hydrogen-bonded network is shown in Figure B.

The three solvent water molecules and the six coordinated water molecules in the trinuclear molecule are involved in many hydrogen bonds, as listed in Table . The hydrogen-bonded network is shown in Figure B.

elements.content: As in 1, there are considerable π-stacking and C−H/π interactions in 2. One of the CH2- groups, C(74) of hexamine is engaged in two Csp 3-H/π interactions (Table ) with the two phenyl rings of a neighboring trinuclear unit (1 − x, 2 − y, −z) as shown in Figure to form a 1D array of the molecules in the “a” direction. Interestingly, the C−H/π distances are very short compared to the standard ones, indicating that the cadmium atoms coordinated to hmt increment the acidity of the hydrogen atoms that participate in the interaction. There are also strong π−π interactions between the terminal phenyl rings of the bidentate benzoate with that of neighboring (1 − x, 2 − y, −1 − z) trinuclear units with a slip angle of 17.0°, dihedral angle of 3.9°, and centroid separation of 3.66 (1) Å to form a 1D chain along the b axis. The C−H/π and π−π interactions together form the 2D sheet structure in the compound.

elements.content: In contrast to 1 and 2, complex 3 contains only one cadmium atom in the asymmetric unit, but the structure, shown in Figure , is a 1D polymer. In 3 the metal atom also has a seven-coordinate pentagonal bipyramidal environment being bonded to two bidentate benzoates (2.36(1)−2.43(1) Å) and one water molecule at 2.31(1) Å in the equatorial plane, with a rms deviation of 0.215 Å for the contributing atoms, see Figure and Table S4, Supporting Information. The metal atom is 0.003 Å from this plane. There are two bridging hmt ligands in axial positions at 2.44(1) and 2.46(1) Å, thus creating the 1D polymer.

Complex 3 

In contrast to 1 and 2, complex 3 contains only one cadmium atom in the asymmetric unit, but the structure, shown in Figure , is a 1D polymer. In 3 the metal atom also has a seven-coordinate pentagonal bipyramidal environment being bonded to two bidentate benzoates (2.36(1)-2.43(1) Å) and one water molecule at 2.31(1) Å in the equatorial plane, with a rms deviation of 0.215 Å for the contributing atoms, see Figure  and Table S4, Supporting Information. The metal atom is 0.003 Å from this plane. There are two bridging hmt ligands in axial positions at 2.44(1) and 2.46(1) Å, thus creating the 1D polymer.

elements.content: The water molecule O(1) bonded to the metal forms two donor hydrogen bonds to the oxygen atoms O(13) and O(21) of two chelated phenyl acetate moieties, both at symmetry element (x − 1, y, z) of an adjacent chain. By comparison with 1 and 2, more hydrogen atoms of hexamine in 3 are involved in noteworthy C−H/π interactions. Three H-atoms [H(32b), H(34a), and H(36b)] interact with the phenyl ring of one of the coordinated phenyl acetate group and in addition H(37a) of the same hexamine molecule interacts with the phenyl ring of a second phenyl acetate of an adjacent molecule (−1/2 + x, 1/2 − y, −1/2 + z) within the chain by means of weak Csp 3-H/π supramolecular interactions (Figure A). Furthermore, one of the phenyl rings of phenylacetate interacts by means of Csp 2-H/π (donor) (−1/2 + x, 1/2 − y, −1/2 + z) and the other one by Csp 2-H/π (acceptor) interactions with two neighboring chains to form a 2D network. These Csp 2-H/π contact parameters are typical for this type of interaction. In addition, there are π−π interactions between the phenyl rings (1 − x, 1 − y, −z) which act as Csp 2-H/π donor. There is cooperativity between Csp 2-H/π and π−π interactions (Figure B), which is demonstrated below. Figure illustrates the supramolecular interactions observed in complex 3.

elements.content: The polymeric structure of 4 is shown in Figure . There are three independent metal atoms in the asymmetric unit, all having similar seven-coordinate pentagonal bipyramidal environments with two bidentate acetates and a water molecule in the equatorial plane with two bridging hmt ligands in axial positions. However, unlike the other three compounds, in this case each hmt ligand is bridging to two further cadmium atoms (μ3-bridging mode) thus forming a 2D polymer with fused hexagonal rings (Figure A). Each hexagon is in the usual chair conformation and presents six three-connected hmt ligands at the vertices, joined by six trans-connected cadmium ions acting only as linear spacers. It is to be noted that a 2D net with this type of hexagonal units is very rare and documented primarily with Ag-hmt systems.

elements.content: In this complex, one hmt bonds to three metal atoms, via N(11) to Cd(2), N(15) to Cd(1) and N(17) to Cd(1) (symmetry element −1/2 + x, −y, z), while the other hmt bonds similarly via N(41) to Cd(3), N(45) to Cd(1) and N(47) to Cd(3) (symmetry element −1/2 + x, −1 − y, z). In the three equatorial planes around the metal atoms, the contributing atoms show rms deviations of 0.210, 0.245, 0.338 Å with the metal atoms 0.042(2), 0.010(3), 0.003(2) Å from the respective planes. The bond lengths to the water molecules are similar in the range 2.27(1)−2.29(1) Å. However, there are significant variations in the distances from the metal to the bidentate acetates. In particular for both Cd(2) and Cd(3), one of the acetates is asymmetrically bonded, and thus bond lengths Cd(2)−O(67), Cd(2)−O(65) are 2.32 (1), 2.55(1) Å and Cd(3)−C(75), Cd(3)−O(77) are 2.54 (1), 2.32 (1) Å, respectively. All other acetates including both on Cd(1) are symmetrically bound. The Cd−N distances in the axial positions range from 2.39(1) to 2.47(1) Å. The three water molecules bonded to the metal atoms together with the six solvent water molecules participate in extensive hydrogen bonding (Figure B), and details are provided in Table .

elements.content: Two separate studies were carried out. First we used models created from fragments of the crystal structures to analyze the effect of the presence of cadmium coordinated to the hexamine upon the strength of the C−H/π interactions and the mutual influence of the π−π and C−H/π interactions. These models were created taking into account the need to reduce the size of the system in order to allow the use of high level ab initio calculations. This part has been done at the RI-MP2/TZVP and RI-MP2/aug-cc-pVTZ levels of theory. Second, an AIM analysis of the complex 3 was carried out using DFT calculations in order to characterize the noncovalent interactions that are relevant in the solid state.
elements.clean_text:
Theoretical Study

Two separate studies were carried out. First we used models created from fragments of the crystal structures to analyze the effect of the presence of cadmium coordinated to the hexamine upon the strength of the C-H/π interactions and the mutual influence of the π-π and C-H/π interactions. These models were created taking into account the need to reduce the size of the system in order to allow the use of high level ab initio calculations. This part has been done at the RI-MP2/TZVP and RI-MP2/aug-cc-pVTZ levels of theory. Second, an AIM analysis of the complex 3 was carried out using DFT calculations in order to characterize the noncovalent interactions that are relevant in the solid state.

elements.content: Schematic representation of the theoretical models a−c.
elements.clean_text: 9  Schematic representation of the theoretical models a-c.

elements.content: The models used to carry out the first study are shown in Figure . We have computed the interaction energy of compounds 5 and 6 in order to evaluate the effect of the coordination of cadmium to hmt on the C−H/π interaction (model “a”). The energetic and geometric results are summarized in Table . The interaction energy of complex 5 is −12.96 kJ/mol; thus each C−H/π interaction contributes approximately −4.3 kJ/mol, in agreement with state of the art calculations on C−H/π interactions, thus validating our methodology. Interestingly, the computed interaction energy of complex 6 is −14.71 kJ/mol, thus 1.75 kJ/mol more favorable than 5, indicating that the C−H/π interaction is reinforced by the presence of cadmium. The optimized geometries are represented in Figure . Taking into account that the hmt is coordinated to two cadmium atoms in the real system, it is expected that this reinforcement would be greater, enhancing these noncovalent interactions as strong binding motifs in the crystal. In order to study the effect of two cadmium atom coordinated to hmt, we have studied the hypothetical equilibrium between 7a and 7b (see model “b”, Figure ). We have found that 7a is 15.00 kJ/mol more stable than 7b. At first sight, it might appear that this energy is inconsistent when compared to the binding energy of 6 (only one cadmium atom) which is −14.71 kJ/mol. However, complex 7b exhibits an extra N−H/π interaction that is not present in 7a (see Figure ). In the crystal structure where the carboxylate ion is phenylacetate, an interesting combination of π−π and C−H/π interactions is observed (see Figure B). We have used model “c” (see Figure ) to study the influence of the π−π interaction on the C−H/π interaction and vice versa. We have first computed the binary complexes 8 (T-shape benzene dimer) and 9 (parallel-displaced benzene dimer), and the energetic and geometric features are listed in Table . It can be observed that the quaternary complex 10 has a computed binding energy (−80.13 kJ/mol) that is more negative than the sum of the binding energy of 9 and two times the energy of 8 (−74.63 kJ/mol), indicating that there is a favorable cooperativity between both interactions. It is worth mentioning that the equilibrium distance of the π−π interaction is significantly shorter in 10 than in 9, indicating a reinforcement of this interaction. By contrast a lengthening of the C−H/π interaction is observed because of the geometry of the quaternary complex deviates from the ideal interacting angle (see Figure ). This is due to the presence of one of the rings of the benzene dimer that influences the C−H/π interaction of the other.

Finally, we have performed an AIM analysis of the two crystal fragments (A and B), shown in Figure . Both fragments have been obtained from the crystallographic coordinates of complex 3. In fragment A three phenyl acetate ions have been replaced by three acetate ions and one hexamine has been replaced by ammonia, in order to reduce the computational cost. It can be observed that the C−H/π interaction between hexamine and the phenyl ring is characterized by the presence of two bond (3, −1) and two ring (3, +1) critical points (CP). The interaction is further described by one cage (3, +3) CP, as is common in this type of interaction. The value of the Laplacian at the CPs is positive, indicating a closed shell noncovalent interaction. In fragment B, where two types of noncovalent interaction coexist, we have obtained the following distribution of critical points. For the C−H/π interaction, we have found two bond CPs that connect two Csp 2-H hydrogen atoms with two carbon atoms of the ring. As a consequence of this, one ring CP is also formed. For the π−π interaction, two bond, three ring, and two cage CPs describe the interaction. We have used the AIM results to corroborate the cooperativity effect observed in this arrangement where both interactions act simultaneously. Since the value of the density (ρ) at the cage CP can be successfully used as a measure of bond order in noncovalent interactions involving aromatic rings, we have obtained the distribution of the critical points in a fragment of the crystal where only the two stacked ring are included and the other two rings have been eliminated. In this system, the value of ρ at the cage CPs is 103ρ = 2.4390 au, which is lower than that computed in fragment A (103ρ = 2.6093 au). This indicates that the π−π stacking interaction is stronger when the phenyl rings participate in C−H/π interactions simultaneously, in agreement with the energetic and geometric results.

elements.content: Four new cadmium(II) complexes have been synthesized using three monocarboxylate ions and characterized structurally. All the Cd atoms (apart from one of the Cd atoms in 2) possess seven-coordinate pentagonal bipyramidal geometry where bidentate carboxylate groups, hexamine, and water molecules act as ligands. Although the complexes are prepared in a very similar way using the same hmt/Cd ratios the composition, nuclearity, coordination modes of hmt and the final molecular structures of the self-assembled species are very different. The discrete di- and trinuclear structures of 1 and 2 respectively are remarkable since such structures are unprecedented when all known hmt-Cd(II) coordination polymers are considered. In both 1 and 2, the coordination of a water molecule to the axial position of Cd(II) instead of an hmt terminate the propagation of the polymeric chain like compound 3. The fused hexagonal ring structure of 4 with μ3-bridging mode of hmt is a very rare type in CdII-hmt polymer chemistry. We have studied the noncovalent interactions (H-bonds, C−H/π, and π−π interactions) which play key roles in the self-assembly of the supramolecular network in the complexes. Using high level ab initio calculations, we have demonstrated that hmt can be involved in significant C−H/π interactions with the phenyl ring and that the cadmium atom coordinated to hexamine enhances considerably the C−H/π interactions, in agreement with the short distances observed in the solid state. Finally, the interplay between C−H/π and π−π interactions has been analyzed, and we have found that the presence of the simultaneous C−H/π interactions enhance the π−π interaction, in terms of geometry and energy. This issue has been confirmed using Bader’s AIM theory. This interplay can be important in deciding the crystal packing.
elements.clean_text:
Concluding Remarks

Four new cadmium(II) complexes have been synthesized using three monocarboxylate ions and characterized structurally. All the Cd atoms (apart from one of the Cd atoms in 2) possess seven-coordinate pentagonal bipyramidal geometry where bidentate carboxylate groups, hexamine, and water molecules act as ligands. Although the complexes are prepared in a very similar way using the same hmt/Cd ratios the composition, nuclearity, coordination modes of hmt and the final molecular structures of the self-assembled species are very different. The discrete di- and trinuclear structures of 1 and 2 respectively are remarkable since such structures are unprecedented when all known hmt-Cd(II) coordination polymers are considered. In both 1 and 2, the coordination of a water molecule to the axial position of Cd(II) instead of an hmt terminate the propagation of the polymeric chain like compound 3. The fused hexagonal ring structure of 4 with μ3-bridging mode of hmt is a very rare type in CdII-hmt polymer chemistry. We have studied the noncovalent interactions (H-bonds, C-H/π, and π-π interactions) which play key roles in the self-assembly of the supramolecular network in the complexes. Using high level ab initio calculations, we have demonstrated that hmt can be involved in significant C-H/π interactions with the phenyl ring and that the cadmium atom coordinated to hexamine enhances considerably the C-H/π interactions, in agreement with the short distances observed in the solid state. Finally, the interplay between C-H/π and π-π interactions has been analyzed, and we have found that the presence of the simultaneous C-H/π interactions enhance the π-π interaction, in terms of geometry and energy. This issue has been confirmed using Bader's AIM theory. This interplay can be important in deciding the crystal packing.

Benzoic acid (0.488 g, 4 mmol) dissolved in methanol (10 cm3) was added to a methanolic solution (10 cm3) of Cd(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.838 g, 2 mmol) and hmt (0.560 g, 4 mmol) with constant stirring. The solution was filtered to remove a small amount of precipitate that appeared immediately and the filtrate was left at room temperature. Colorless crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray determination were collected from the filtrate after a few days. Yield: 0.605 g (57%). Anal. Calc. for C41H48Cd2N4O15: C, 46.38; H, 4.56; N, 5.28; Found: C, 46.21; H, 4.68; N, 5.22%. The solution was left at room temperature and colorless crystals of 2 suitable for X-ray determination were collected after a few days. Yield: 0.531 g (51%). Anal. The solution obtained after filtration was left at room temperature, and colorless crystals of 3 suitable for X-ray analysis appeared in a few days. Yield: 0.834 g (43%). Anal. cln_elements.content: Compound 1 upon heating loses its water molecules in one step which starts at 90 °C and is completed at 140 °C as is evident from the thermogravimetry (TG)−differential TG (DTG) curve (). The observed weight loss corresponds to five molecules of water per formula unit. The crystals turn opaque on the removal of water molecules but do not break into powder. This dehydrated species on exposure to the open atmosphere for several hours absorbs exactly five molecules of water per formula unit, and no more water molecules were absorbed on keeping for longer periods. The water loss behavior of rehydrated species as found in the TG-DTG curve is identical to that of the original sample. These observations indicate that the framework integrity of 1 remains intact upon removal of the water molecules. The dehydration behavior of complexes 2−4 is very similar. The weight loss for dehydration (up to 150 °C) for the complexes corroborates the number of water molecules present in the structure of the respective compounds (Table S1, ).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetry

Compound 1 upon heating loses its water molecules in one step which starts at 90 °C and is completed at 140 °C as is evident from the thermogravimetry (TG)-differential TG (DTG) curve (). The observed weight loss corresponds to five molecules of water per formula unit. The crystals turn opaque on the removal of water molecules but do not break into powder. This dehydrated species on exposure to the open atmosphere for several hours absorbs exactly five molecules of water per formula unit, and no more water molecules were absorbed on keeping for longer periods. The water loss behavior of rehydrated species as found in the TG-DTG curve is identical to that of the original sample. These observations indicate that the framework integrity of 1 remains intact upon removal of the water molecules. The dehydration behavior of complexes 2-4 is very similar. The weight loss for dehydration (up to 150 °C) for the complexes corroborates the number of water molecules present in the structure of the respective compounds (Table S1, ).

Two views of complex 1. (A) The dinuclear structure with ellipsoids drawn at 30% probability. (B) The hydrogen bonding network. The phenyl rings and hydrogen atoms, except for those belonging to water molecules, have been omitted for the sake of clarity. Hydrogen bonds are shown as dotted lines.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Two views of complex 1. (A) The dinuclear structure with ellipsoids drawn at 30% probability. (B) The hydrogen bonding network. The phenyl rings and hydrogen atoms, except for those belonging to water molecules, have been omitted for the sake of clarity. Hydrogen bonds are shown as dotted lines.

cln_elements.content: Two views of complex 1. (A) The C−H/π interactions between hexamine and the phenyl rings and the hydrogen bonds between the neutral benzoic acid and the dinuclear complex are highlighted. (B) The π−π, C−H/π, and hydrogen bonding interactions are represented by orange dashed, blue dashed, and gray dotted lines, respectively. Relevant hydrogen atoms are represented by gray spheres.
